text: My name is Lisa. I am 26 years old. I live in a small town in the US. When I was young, I wanted a happy life. I wanted to get married. I wanted
one or two children. I wanted a small house and a good man. I thought love was easy. But I was wrong. I met Mark when I was 22.
He was 25. He was tall. He had brown hair and blue eyes. He was funny. He smiled a lot. He liked to talk. We met at a
friend's party. He asked for my phone number. I gave it to him. The next day, he sent me a message. He asked, "Do you want to meet for
coffee?" I said, "Yes." We met in town. We talked for a long time. I liked him. After that, we saw each other many times. He made me
laugh. He gave me flowers. He called me every night. After 3 months, I told him, "I love you." He said, "I love you, too." I believed him.
We were together for one year. I worked at a grocery store. Mark worked at a car repair shop.
We didn't have much money, but I was happy. Then something changed. One day I felt sick in the morning. I thought I had a cold, but the
next day I felt sick again.
My best friend Sarah said, "Maybe you are pregnant." I said, "No, I don't think so." But I was not sure. I bought a test. I
waited. The test showed I was pregnant.
I was shaking. I looked at it. I was pregnant. That night, I went to Mark's apartment. I looked at him and said, "I have
news." He looked at me and asked, "What is it?" I said, "I am going to have a baby." He was quiet. He looked at the floor. He did not speak for a long
time. Then he said, "Are you sure?" I said yes I did a test I am sure. He stood up.
He went to the window. He looked outside. He did not look at me. This is not a good time. He said I am not ready to be a
father. I felt cold. I felt sick.
I said, "But we love each other." He said nothing. He just said, "I need time to think." That night, he did not hold me or kiss me. I could not
sleep. In the morning, he left early. He said, "See you later." But I knew something was wrong.
After that, everything changed. He stopped calling me. He stopped answering my messages. He didn't want to see me. One day, I went to his
apartment. I knocked on the door. He did not open it. I sent him one last message. He replied, "I can't do this.
I'm sorry.
That was the last time I heard from Mark. I sat on my bed and cried. I cried for hours. I could not believe it. I was
pregnant and alone. I told my mom and dad. My mom cried with me. My dad said nothing. Then he said, "We are here for you, Lisa."
I moved back to my parents' house. I felt like a child, but I was not. I was going to be a mother. Every day, I felt more tired. My belly grew
bigger. I went to the doctor. I saw my baby on the screen. I heard her heartbeat. I smiled and cried at the same time.
I worked at the grocery store until the baby was born. I bought small clothes in a crib.
I wanted to be ready. One night, I had strong pain. My mom took me to the hospital. The nurse said, "You were going to have the baby
tonight. I was scared.
The pain was very strong. I held my mom's hand. After many hours, I heard a small cry. The nurse said, "It's a girl." They gave her to me. She was
small. She was soft and warm. I looked at her and smiled. I said, "Hello, baby. I am your mom. I named her Emma. She was
beautiful. I stayed in the hospital for two days. Then I went home. My mom helped me with Emma, but at night it was just me and my baby. Emma cried a
lot. I was very tired. I did not sleep much. I changed her diapers.
I fed her. I held her when she cried. Sometimes I sat on the bed and cried, too. I was very tired, but I looked at her small
face. I kissed her head and said, "I love you." Mark never came. He never called. He did not ask about Emma.
One day I saw him in town. He walked past me. He looked at me then looked away. He said nothing. I wanted to shout. I wanted to
ask, "How can you leave your baby?" But I said nothing. I just looked down at Emma in her stroller. When Emma was 5 months old, I
went back to work. My mom watched her when I was working. I missed Emma every minute, but I needed the money. At work, I smiled and said hello to
customers. I carried boxes. I stood on my feet for hours. When I got home, I was tired, but Emma needed me. I cooked dinner. I cleaned the house.
I fed Emma. I bathed her. I put her to sleep. I never stopped. One night, Emma was sleeping. I sat in the kitchen and drank cold
tea. I looked at the wall. I felt tired but strong. I told myself, "You are tired, Lisa.
But you are doing okay. I smiled because I was now a mother. Emma grew fast. She smiled more each day. When she was 6 months old, she sat by
herself. She played with her toys. I watched her and smiled.
Sometimes I cried too. I was proud of her. I was also tired. Every day was busy. I worked, cleaned, and cared for Emma. But she gave me
strength. I did not have many friends. My old friends did not visit much. They had busy lives. They went out at night. They posted happy pictures
online. I stayed at home.
I watched cartoons with Emma. I sang to her when she cried. I told her, "You are not alone. I am here." Before I tell you more, I want to
ask, where are you listening from? Sometimes I wonder if someone out there hears me. someone who understands my feelings. It makes me strong to know I
am not alone. Please tell me in the comments. My mom helped me a lot. She held Emma when I took a shower. She made dinner when I was
tired. My dad did not talk much, but he played with Emma. He made her laugh.
I was thankful for my parents. Without them, life would be harder. Sometimes I saw Mark in town. He never said hello. He just walked
past. One day, Emma was in my arms. Mark looked at us. He looked for a second, then walked away.
I held Emma closer. I kissed her head. I told myself, "You don't need him. I will give you everything." Money was a big
problem. My job at the grocery store did not pay much. I bought only what we needed. Baby food, diapers, warm clothes. I did not buy clothes for
myself. I wore old jeans and simple shirts. I did not care about how I looked. I only cared about Emma. At work, I was quiet. I did my
job. I smiled at customers. But inside, I was tired. My feet hurt. My back hurt.
But I always said, "I am okay." When Emma was sick, I stayed home.
My boss was not happy. He said, "You can't miss so many days." I said, "My baby needs me." He said, "Be careful. You need this job." I felt
scared. I did not want to lose my job. I needed it for Emma. At home, Emma started to stand.
She held the side of the sofa and smiled. She looked proud. I clapped and said, "Good job." She laughed. Her laugh made me
happy. Her laugh made the house warm. One evening, Emma had a fever. Her head was hot.
She cried and would not eat. I called the doctor. He said, "It may be a virus. Keep her cool and give her water." I held her all
night. I did not sleep. I was afraid. I sang soft songs and said, "Please get better." In the morning, she still had a
fever. My mom said, "Let's go to the clinic. We went." The nurse gave Emma medicine. She said she will be okay. I felt better. I kissed Emma's warm
cheek. Emma got stronger. She started walking at 13 months.
She fell many times but got up again. I clapped for her. She smiled with all her teeth. My heart was full. I said, "You are so brave." Time went
by. Emma turned two. She started to talk more. She said, "Mama ball." and milk. She liked to dance. She liked to play with socks and shoes. I laughed
when she put her tiny foot in my big shoe. She looked serious. One Sunday, I took her to the park. She ran on the grass. She saw other
children. She waved at them. One boy gave her a toy car. She smiled.
I sat on a bench and watched her. The sun was warm. I felt peaceful. Then I saw Mark again. He was at the other end of the park. He was with another
woman. She had red hair. They held hands. I looked away.
I did not want Emma to see him. She did not know him. He was her father, but he was not in her life. That night, I thought about that moment. I did not
cry. I just looked at the wall and sat on the bed. I thought he chose to walk away. I will not wait for him.
I will not beg. I looked at Emma. She was asleep. She looked safe and happy. I whispered, "You have me and that is enough." A few days later, I got a
letter from the housing office. They said I could get a small apartment. It was not big. But it was mine. I felt excited. I packed our
things. My mom helped me. We put Emma's toys in a box. We folded her clothes. My dad drove us to the new apartment. The apartment had one
bedroom, one bathroom, and a small kitchen. The walls were white. The floor was clean. I put Emma's bed near mine. I put a photo of us on the
table. We ate dinner on the floor that night. We had toast and tea. Emma laughed and dropped a spoon. I picked it up and
smiled. I said, "This is our home now." In the new apartment, life was quiet but hard. I worked. I took care of Emma. I
paid rent. I cooked simple meals. I read bedtime stories. Emma liked books with animals.
She liked the one with the blue bear. She said, "Bar is funny." I kissed her and said, "You are funny, too.
Some nights I felt lonely. I missed talking to someone. I missed hugs, but I never missed Mark. I did not want someone who left. I wanted peace. I
wanted love that stayed. One day at work, a woman came to my checkout. She had a baby in a stroller. She looked tired like me.
She smiled and said, "It's hard, isn't it?" I smiled and said, "Yes, but they are worth it." She said, "You're doing a good
job." Her words made me feel good. That night, I told Emma, "You are my sunshine." She smiled and hugged me. I was still tired. I was still
poor, but I was not broken. I was strong. I was a mother. Emma was now 3 years old. She could talk more. She asked many
questions. She asked, "Why is the sky blue? Where do birds sleep?" I smiled and answered simply. She was smart. She liked to
learn. She liked to sing and dance. Her laugh was my favorite sound.
We had a simple life. We lived in our small apartment. We had a routine. I woke up early. I made breakfast. Emma ate
slowly. She always wanted one more spoon of yogurt. I took her to daycare near our home. Then I went to work. Every day was the same. But I did not
mind. I had peace. I had my child. I had a reason to wake up. At night, Emma sat on my lap. I read her stories. She always asked for the same
book about the red bus.
She said, "The bus goes beep beep." I laughed. I kissed her and said, "Sleep now, baby." She closed her eyes and held my
hand. Sometimes I looked at her face in the dark. I thought about the past. I thought about the pain. I also thought about the love.
My life was not easy, but I was proud. One day, I got a letter from Emma's daycare.
It said, "Emma is ready for school next year." My eyes filled with tears.
"School? My baby is growing up. She is not a baby anymore." I told her the news. She clapped and said, "School, I want a pink
bag." I smiled. "You will get a pink bag and new shoes." I said, "That weekend, we went shopping.
We looked at school bags. Emma touched each one. She said, "Too big, too small." Then she saw a pink one with stars.
She held it and smiled. We went home. Emma wore the bag inside the house. She walked around like a little student. I
laughed. I felt happy and sad. I was proud of her. But I also felt scared. She was growing so fast. Time went by.
Emma turned four. She was taller. Her hair was longer. She made friends. She said, "Mom, my friend is Lucy. She has a dog." I said, "That's
nice." She asked, "Can we get a dog?" I said, "Maybe one day." I worked more hours now. My boss gave me extra shifts. I said yes to everyone. I
needed more money. I wanted Emma to have more. Sometimes I felt tired, but I always told myself, "You can do this, Lisa." One Friday, I came home
late. My mom was there. She watched Emma that evening.
I took off my shoes. Emma ran to me. She said, "Mommy, you're home." I hugged her tight. My mom smiled and said she missed
you. I looked at my daughter and felt something deep inside. After my mom left, I made tea. Emma played with her doll.
Then she looked at me and asked, "Mom, do I have a dad?" My hand froze. I looked at her. I sat next to her. Why do you ask? I
said. She said, "At school, my friend said her dad picks her up. Do I have a dad, too?" I felt a little pain in my chest.
I held her hand. I said, "Yes, you have a dad." "But he does not live with us," she asked. "Why not?" I said, "He made a
choice. He did not want to stay." She looked at me with soft eyes. She said, "But I have you." I smiled and kissed her head.
Yes, I said. You have me and I will never leave. That night I cried a little in the kitchen. I cried quietly. I did not want her to hear. I
just needed to let it out. One evening, a woman from Emma's school came to talk to me. She said, "I'm Emma's teacher. She is doing well.
She is kind and curious.
I smiled. The teacher said, "You are doing a good job. She is a happy girl." Her words stayed in my heart. I was trying my best. Maybe my best was
enough. Emma started school that year.
She wore a new uniform. She held my hand tightly on her first day.
I said, "You are brave. You will do great." She asked, "Will you wait for me?" I said, "Yes, I will always wait for you." She went into
the classroom. She looked back and waved. I smiled and waved back. Then I sat on a bench outside.
I cried again, not because I was sad, but because I was proud. Our life was still simple. I still worked long hours. I
still counted every coin, but I had a little girl who smiled at me every morning. She said, "Good morning, Mom." With joy, that was more than
enough. One Sunday, Emma and I went to the park. She ran and played. I sat on a bench and watched her. A man sat next to me. He said, "Is
she your daughter?" I said, "Yes." He said, "She looks happy." I smiled. I said, "She is." He said, "That's all that matters." I looked at
Emma. I thought about everything. The tears, the nights alone, the fear. Then I looked at her bright smile, her strong little legs, her big
eyes. Yes, I thought she is happy. And I did it all alone. If you liked my story, please like, comment, and share. More simple and emotional stories
are coming soon.
